title: The Day of the LORD
shortSummary: Malachi 4 prophesies the coming day of the LORD, a time of judgment for the wicked and blessing for the faithful. It promises the arrival of Elijah before this great day, emphasizing repentance and restoration within families. This chapter serves as a powerful conclusion to the prophetic warnings and hope found throughout Malachi.
timeline: c. 5th century BC - Post-exilic period, after the return from Babylonian captivity

keyCharacters.name: Elijah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet whom God promises to send before the great and dreadful day of the LORD to call the people to repentance and restore family relationships.

keyCharacters.name: The Proud and Wicked
keyCharacters.description: Those who reject God’s ways and live in rebellion; they face destruction on the day of the LORD.

keyCharacters.name: The Fearers of the LORD
keyCharacters.description: Those who reverence God's name and will experience healing and blessing when the Sun of righteousness arises.

definitions.definition: A Messianic title symbolizing Jesus Christ, who brings healing, righteousness, and salvation to His people.
The dry, leftover stalks after grain harvest; used metaphorically here to represent the wicked who will be completely consumed by judgment.

definitions.term: The great and dreadful day of the LORD
definitions.definition: A future time of God's decisive judgment and intervention in history, bringing justice and restoration.
A key Old Testament prophet who will return in spirit and power to prepare the people for the coming day of the LORD.

outline.heading: Judgment on the Wicked
outline.description: God declares that the coming day will burn like an oven, consuming the proud and wicked completely, leaving them no root or branch. Conversely, those who fear God will be healed and victorious over evil.

outline.heading: Call to Remember the Law
outline.description: The people are exhorted to remember and obey the law given to Moses at Horeb, emphasizing the continuing relevance of God's statutes and judgments.

outline.heading: Promise of Elijah’s Return
outline.description: God promises to send Elijah before the great day of the LORD to turn hearts and bring reconciliation between generations, preventing judgment by restoring relationships.

application: Live with reverence and fear of the LORD, trusting in His promise of healing and righteousness.
Remember and obey God’s Word as revealed in Scripture, allowing it to guide your daily life and decisions.
Pray for restoration in family relationships, seeking reconciliation as a testimony of God’s transforming power.
Anticipate Christ’s return with readiness, living in holiness and faithfulness as the day of the LORD approaches.

keyVerses.text: But unto you that fear my name shall the Sun of righteousness arise with healing in his wings; and ye shall go forth, and grow up as calves of the stall.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the hope and healing available to those who reverence God, pointing to Christ as the source of righteousness and restoration.

keyVerses.text: Behold, I will send you Elijah the prophet before the coming of the great and dreadful day of the LORD:
keyVerses.significance: This verse foretells the prophetic ministry of Elijah as a forerunner to Christ’s return, emphasizing the call to repentance and preparation.

keyVerses.text: For, behold, the day cometh, that shall burn as an oven; and all the proud, yea, and all that do wickedly, shall be stubble: and the day that cometh shall burn them up, saith the LORD of hosts, that it shall leave them neither root nor branch.
keyVerses.significance: This verse warns of the certainty and severity of God’s judgment against the wicked, underscoring the holiness and justice of God.
